Fresh out of school, Bob Wilson,'53,
was put to work on a Transistor project
at Bell Laboratories. He explains why
he never had time to be awed.

MARCH 11th

Boa WILSON works on a "breadboard" circuit, studying the electrical properties of a carrier system.

"In some ways it was hard to believe. I
had received my B.E.E. at the University of Delaware in June, 1953, and a
week later I was working in the worldfamous Bell Laboratories.
"But I didn't have time to be awed because they put me right to work. They
gave me responsibility fast.
"My group was working on the experimental application of transistors to carrier
systems. My assignment was the electrical design of a variolosser for the compressor and for the expandor to be located
in the terminals.
"The supervision I received and the
equipment I had were tops. I quickly discovered that I had to rely on my ingenuity
as much as on the college courses I had
taken. Perhaps that's one reason for the

great new discoveries continually turned
out by the Labs.
"Now, I'm in the Communication Development Training Program, continuing
my technical education and learning what
all the Laboratories sections do and how
their work is integrated.
"In a year I'll be back working with
the group with which I started."
•

•

•

Assuming responsibility fast is a common
experience among the engineering, physical science, arts and social science, and
business administration graduates who join
the Bell System. Bob Wilson went with
Bell Laboratories. There also are job opportunities with the operating telephone
companies, Western Electric and Sandia
Corporation.

BELL TELEPHONE SYSTEM

For Pershing Rifles

E. Ritter
The Pershing Rifles initiated Zymen
14 pledges in ceremonies at the Mayer
ROTC building on February 12. A. Waskow

The pledges had satisfactorily
completed a period of training
which included practicing drill
and learning the ideals and history of the Pershing Rifles.
Eamon McGeady, Captain of the
Pershing Rifles, announced that
the organization's future activities
included participation in the Annual Regimental Drill, a night
problem, and a trick drill.

An Immature Action
The recent escapades o- f some members of Phi Gamma Delta
points out one of the prime weaknesses in the argument of the
social fraternities that they make a positive contribution to the
development of the individual. Some twenty or more Phi Gams,
completely independent of any fraternity sanction or formal
knowledge, visited the ,Goucher College campus last Thursday,
and while they were there destroyed several sections of copper
downspouting on one of the dormitories.

•
People who dislike the custom of social fraternities argue
that the groups encourage just such irresponsible and immature
actions 0'this. It seems unnecessary to point out that the actions
of these men will more than outweigh the information the News.Idetter published last week on the Help Week program or the IFB's
Heart Fund work. Similarly, if the Phi Gams involved were to
pay three times the damage involved, it still would not erase
the bad publicity.
It is unfortunate that the 500 fraternity men on campus
should have to suffer from the actions of 20 unthinking students.
Indirectly, though, all of them, and even the University as a
whole, will suffer. The least Phi Gam as a fraternity can do is
to make good the whole damage, regardless of the final cost, and
regardless of how much of this amount they can collect from the
men involved. If they do not do this, the IFB, for its own Protection, should force them to take action. It is true that this course
of action would place a burden on the fraternity which is in
some respects unfair, but it is still more just than leaving Goucher
College out of poeket for something they did not in any way\invite.

Joe College Meets Academic Freedom
The Hopkins YMCA opens its two-day Academic Freedom
Conference this evening at Levering Hall. On a campus which
is dedicated largely to intellectual pursuits, it adds to activities
a discussion of academic freedom, among the noblest of intellectual concepts. Not only all Hopkins students, but representatives
of neighboring campuses have been invited.
The moving force behind this innovation is Dr. Chester
Wickwire, the executive secretary at Levering, whose energy
and perseverance helped to create the conference. Credit is due
also to the Y's new president, Ed Freeman, and his cabinet for
carrying out the plans, and to "co-participants"—The Woodrow
Wilson Club, the Students for Democratic Action, and the
Student Committee for Academic Freedom—for sharing the
work.
Until now the defense of academic freedom upon the Hopkins
campus has been the function of these three groups of specialized
but limited appeal. For the Wilson Club, the campus Democrats,
their main interest is that the present assailants of academic
freedom attack the Democratic Party with the same vitriolic outbursts. For the SDA, academic freedom is merely one bright
thread in the overall fabric of liberal ideals, while the SCAF
contains mostly graduate students, for whom such freedom is
directly a matter of self-preservation. These groups serve their
purposes, but they cannot arouse the masses of students.
But the YMCA is an organization of broad cultural and
social interests, to which a large portion of the undergrads belong.
As such it has an obligation to instill in Joe College a little
responsibility and interest in the issues relating to his campus
liberties.

INTRAMURALS COULD BE BETTER
Intramural athletics are an important phase of the Hopkins
athletic program, but it is the belief of many that here too, there
is much room for improvement. The Nester (who, by the way,
is a vice president of the present Board of Intramural Athletics)
is inclined to agree,with the opinion that the intramural set-up
isn't nearly as good as it could or should be at Hopkins.
The intramural program on this caMpus has prominent
position in the mind of Mr. Marshall Turner, so he says, but
actually it doesn't seem that way from the Nester's viewpoint.
The budget allotted to intramurls is by no means adequate to
handle the vast number of students presently participating in
the program. Also, the present fourteen-man board is not adequately set up and consequently not run correctly from the
Nester's standpoint. Many participants in the intramural program have complained about the work done by the board, but
actually very few have offered any constructive criticism (and
the BIA is open to this at all times.) It should be remembered
that the men on the Board of Intramural Athletics get nothing
in return for their work and responsibility, and under the
present system, you can actually expect little more from the
Board. The men on it have already done much to give Hopkins
a better intramural program, but their power and scope is
greatly limited. A recent instance of this was brought out when
the BIA made plans to present the fall sports trophy winners
their awards at the opening home basketball contest, but due
to an insignificant tradition of the department of athletics (i.e.
that of buying all awards from a certain person who happened
to be sick at the time) they have yet to be awarded. If the awards
could have been made at the proper time, the intramural program
at Hopkins would have gained much publicity and prominence
en the campus.

PROVIDING ADEQUATE OFFICIALS A PROBLEM
The number one complaint and the biggest problem before
the board each year involves providing adequate officials at all
contests. This is naturally a serious problem, and the Board has
even seriously considered paying trained students to officiate.
However, to the Nester the only way to help this situation is
to have a neutral fraternity provide an official or forfeit a certain number of points. Of course, that will mainly help the interfraternity set up, but the independents could also form a neutral
team providing referees, but this would probably not work nearly
as well.
Other suggestions to improve the present system in intramural athletics and in turn build up interest would be: (1) Have
the BIA composed of one member from each fraternity (with
compulsory attendance or forfeiture of trophy points), plus a
President, Secretary, and three independent students. (2) Have
each fraternity taxed a nominal amount ($1.00 would probably
be sufficient) for each member of its organization who will take
part in intramurals for the year. This money would provide for
the awards, etc. for the interfraternity league, thus giving all of
the present funds for awards to independent sports. (3) Construct an elaborate intramural bulletin board to take the place
of the present one in order to stir up additional interest among
all students, and also make it loss work than is presently involved
in keeping the records up to date.
All of the above mentioned suggestions are within reason
and there should be no drawbacks to any of them. If and when
these steps of iMprovement of our intramural program are taken,
the student interest will certainly grow tremendously. At present
the interest is low, and it is the Nester's belief that only a few
radical changes can improve the situation. These changes call
for some action from the athletic department and especially the
fraternities.

and all athletic department staff
members will be present.

visit to different fraternities. At

MARCH 11th

Boa WILSON works on a "breadboard" circuit, studying the electrical properties of a carrier system.

"In some ways it was hard to believe. I
had received my B.E.E. at the University of Delaware in June, 1953, and a
week later I was working in the worldfamous Bell Laboratories.
"But I didn't have time to be awed because they put me right to work. They
gave me responsibility fast.
"My group was working on the experimental application of transistors to carrier
systems. My assignment was the electrical design of a variolosser for the compressor and for the expandor to be located
in the terminals.
"The supervision I received and the
equipment I had were tops. I quickly discovered that I had to rely on my ingenuity
as much as on the college courses I had
taken. Perhaps that's one reason for the

great new discoveries continually turned
out by the Labs.
"Now, I'm in the Communication Development Training Program, continuing
my technical education and learning what
all the Laboratories sections do and how
their work is integrated.
"In a year I'll be back working with
the group with which I started."
•

•

•

Assuming responsibility fast is a common
experience among the engineering, physical science, arts and social science, and
business administration graduates who join
the Bell System. Bob Wilson went with
Bell Laboratories. There also are job opportunities with the operating telephone
companies, Western Electric and Sandia
Corporation.

An Immature Action
The recent escapades o- f some members of Phi Gamma Delta
points out one of the prime weaknesses in the argument of the
social fraternities that they make a positive contribution to the
development of the individual. Some twenty or more Phi Gams,
completely independent of any fraternity sanction or formal
knowledge, visited the ,Goucher College campus last Thursday,
and while they were there destroyed several sections of copper
downspouting on one of the dormitories.

•
People who dislike the custom of social fraternities argue
that the groups encourage just such irresponsible and immature
actions 0'this. It seems unnecessary to point out that the actions
of these men will more than outweigh the information the News.Idetter published last week on the Help Week program or the IFB's
Heart Fund work. Similarly, if the Phi Gams involved were to
pay three times the damage involved, it still would not erase
the bad publicity.
It is unfortunate that the 500 fraternity men on campus
should have to suffer from the actions of 20 unthinking students.
Indirectly, though, all of them, and even the University as a
whole, will suffer. The least Phi Gam as a fraternity can do is
to make good the whole damage, regardless of the final cost, and
regardless of how much of this amount they can collect from the
men involved. If they do not do this, the IFB, for its own Protection, should force them to take action. It is true that this course
of action would place a burden on the fraternity which is in
some respects unfair, but it is still more just than leaving Goucher
College out of poeket for something they did not in any way\invite.

Joe College Meets Academic Freedom
The Hopkins YMCA opens its two-day Academic Freedom
Conference this evening at Levering Hall. On a campus which
is dedicated largely to intellectual pursuits, it adds to activities
a discussion of academic freedom, among the noblest of intellectual concepts. Not only all Hopkins students, but representatives
of neighboring campuses have been invited.
The moving force behind this innovation is Dr. Chester
Wickwire, the executive secretary at Levering, whose energy
and perseverance helped to create the conference. Credit is due
also to the Y's new president, Ed Freeman, and his cabinet for
carrying out the plans, and to "co-participants"—The Woodrow
Wilson Club, the Students for Democratic Action, and the
Student Committee for Academic Freedom—for sharing the
work.
Until now the defense of academic freedom upon the Hopkins
campus has been the function of these three groups of specialized
but limited appeal. For the Wilson Club, the campus Democrats,
their main interest is that the present assailants of academic
freedom attack the Democratic Party with the same vitriolic outbursts. For the SDA, academic freedom is merely one bright
thread in the overall fabric of liberal ideals, while the SCAF
contains mostly graduate students, for whom such freedom is
directly a matter of self-preservation. These groups serve their
purposes, but they cannot arouse the masses of students.
But the YMCA is an organization of broad cultural and
social interests, to which a large portion of the undergrads belong.
As such it has an obligation to instill in Joe College a little
responsibility and interest in the issues relating to his campus
liberties.

INTRAMURALS COULD BE BETTER
Intramural athletics are an important phase of the Hopkins
athletic program, but it is the belief of many that here too, there
is much room for improvement. The Nester (who, by the way,
is a vice president of the present Board of Intramural Athletics)
is inclined to agree,with the opinion that the intramural set-up
isn't nearly as good as it could or should be at Hopkins.
The intramural program on this caMpus has prominent
position in the mind of Mr. Marshall Turner, so he says, but
actually it doesn't seem that way from the Nester's viewpoint.
The budget allotted to intramurls is by no means adequate to
handle the vast number of students presently participating in
the program. Also, the present fourteen-man board is not adequately set up and consequently not run correctly from the
Nester's standpoint. Many participants in the intramural program have complained about the work done by the board, but
actually very few have offered any constructive criticism (and
the BIA is open to this at all times.) It should be remembered
that the men on the Board of Intramural Athletics get nothing
in return for their work and responsibility, and under the
present system, you can actually expect little more from the
Board. The men on it have already done much to give Hopkins
a better intramural program, but their power and scope is
greatly limited. A recent instance of this was brought out when
the BIA made plans to present the fall sports trophy winners
their awards at the opening home basketball contest, but due
to an insignificant tradition of the department of athletics (i.e.
that of buying all awards from a certain person who happened
to be sick at the time) they have yet to be awarded. If the awards
could have been made at the proper time, the intramural program
at Hopkins would have gained much publicity and prominence
en the campus.

PROVIDING ADEQUATE OFFICIALS A PROBLEM
The number one complaint and the biggest problem before
the board each year involves providing adequate officials at all
contests. This is naturally a serious problem, and the Board has
even seriously considered paying trained students to officiate.
However, to the Nester the only way to help this situation is
to have a neutral fraternity provide an official or forfeit a certain number of points. Of course, that will mainly help the interfraternity set up, but the independents could also form a neutral
team providing referees, but this would probably not work nearly
as well.
Other suggestions to improve the present system in intramural athletics and in turn build up interest would be: (1) Have
the BIA composed of one member from each fraternity (with
compulsory attendance or forfeiture of trophy points), plus a
President, Secretary, and three independent students. (2) Have
each fraternity taxed a nominal amount ($1.00 would probably
be sufficient) for each member of its organization who will take
part in intramurals for the year. This money would provide for
the awards, etc. for the interfraternity league, thus giving all of
the present funds for awards to independent sports. (3) Construct an elaborate intramural bulletin board to take the place
of the present one in order to stir up additional interest among
all students, and also make it loss work than is presently involved
in keeping the records up to date.
All of the above mentioned suggestions are within reason
and there should be no drawbacks to any of them. If and when
these steps of iMprovement of our intramural program are taken,
the student interest will certainly grow tremendously. At present
the interest is low, and it is the Nester's belief that only a few
radical changes can improve the situation. These changes call
for some action from the athletic department and especially the
fraternities.
